title: Nova sede do IPASC/PREVCATALÃO e PRÓ-SAÚDE será inaugurada nesta quinta-feira (21/09) pelo prefeito Adib ...
summary: The new headquarters of IPASC/PREVCATALÃO and PRÓ-SAÚDE will be inaugurated on Thursday, September 21st, by Mayor Adib Elias in Catalão. The facility, built at a cost of R$1.8 million, covers 817.42m² and includes medical and dental offices, triage and reception areas, archives, supply and medical examination rooms, administrative offices, and a communal terrace area. Over 5,000 people, including retirees, pensioners of IPASC, and beneficiaries of Pró-Saúde, will benefit from the enhanced service structure. The building aims to provide better working conditions for its 34 employees and improve the comfort and care of municipal employees and their dependents. Additionally, the inauguration marks the beginning of a primary health care service within Pró-Saúde, focusing on health promotion, prevention, protection, and referral to clinical specialties.

title: Inaugurado por Adib Elias o novo prédio que passa a sediar o IPASC/PREVCATALÃO e o PRÓ-SAÚDE - Portal Zap ...
summary: Adib Elias inaugurated a new building to house the IPASC/PREVCATALÃO and PRÓ-SAÚDE in Catalão. The ceremony took place on the morning of September 21st, at the Av. Raulina Paschoal promenade. The building, which cost R$1.8 million from public funds, spans 817.42m² and is designed to offer better working conditions for the 34 employees and improved comfort for users, including municipal employees and their dependents. It features two medical and dental clinics, a triage room, reception, archives, supplies, medical examination rooms, administrative offices, and a communal terrace area. The initiative also pays tribute to two notable figures, Dr. Aguinaldo Gonçalves Mesquita and Dr. José de Fátimo Moreira, former mayors and physicians, after whom the institutions are named. The IPASC/PREVCATALÃO, established in 1992, is recognized for its consolidated pension security, serving over 5,000 people including retirees, pensioners, and health program beneficiaries.

title: Hospital Municipal Maria Idalina adquire novo equipamento de eletrocardiograma em parceria com Hcor
summary: The Hospital Municipal Maria Idalina, in partnership with the Associação Beneficente Síria (Hcor), acquired a new electrocardiogram (ECG) machine on Tuesday, December 19, 2023, as part of the "Support and Implementation of Good Practices in Cardiology and Cardiovascular Emergencies" project. This new equipment is expected to enhance the hospital's diagnostic capabilities, especially for patients with suspected heart attacks, cardiac arrhythmias, and other cardiological procedures, by providing quicker diagnoses and reducing waiting times for medical regulation. The acquisition is seen as a significant improvement for emergency and prompt care, facilitating better patient outcomes.

title: HSJ implementa protocolo hospitalar que reduz risco de parada cardiorrespiratória
summary: The Hospital São José (HSJ), in partnership with Hcor – Associação Beneficente Síria, the Support Program for Institutional Development of the Unified Health System (Proadi-SUS), and the Ministry of Health, has implemented the National Early Warning Score (NEWS) protocol to reduce the risk of cardiopulmonary arrest. This protocol, aimed at early detection of clinical deterioration, was put into practice from July 2021 to December 2023 in the hospital's Unit C. It involves scoring patients based on predefined criteria such as oxygen saturation, respiratory and heart rates, and body temperature, to identify those at risk of health deterioration and prevent cardiopulmonary arrest. The implementation has led to a significant reduction in emergency codes being triggered, with a 48% decrease in the activation of the Code Red for early deterioration risk and no need to activate the Code Blue for cardiopulmonary arrest in the last four months of the project. The initiative has been deemed a success, with the protocol now firmly integrated into the routine practices of all professionals in the unit.

title: Projeto para refugiados em SP já fez mais de 2.300 atendimentos médicos gratuitos
summary: The Saha Brasil project, aimed at providing medical assistance to refugees in São Paulo, has conducted over 2,300 free medical consultations since its inception in May 2018. The initiative, led by doctors of Arab descent, operates out of the Hcor (Hospital do Coração) and offers services in ten specialties, including orthopedics, gynecology, cardiology, and endocrinology. The project, supported by the Associação Médica Líbano-Brasileira (AMLB) and other organizations, addresses the healthcare needs of refugees from various countries, overcoming language barriers with the help of translators provided by NGOs. It aims to expand its capacity to reduce waiting times and include more specialties like psychiatry. The project is highly rated by patients for its welcoming approach, including greeting patients in their native languages and allowing more time for consultations compared to standard healthcare services.

title: Hcor recebe selo Women on Board, iniciativa apoiada pela ONU Mulheres
summary: Hcor, established in 1976 by a group of women from the Associação Beneficente Síria (ABS), has received the Women on Board seal, supported by UN Women. This award recognizes the hospital's commitment to including women in its Administration Council, which still features or represents its founders. The initiative celebrates companies that incorporate women into their Boards of Directors or Advisory Boards, highlighting the advantages of diversity for businesses and society. Maria Angela Salem Sallum, president of Hcor's Administration Council, stressed the importance of maintaining the institution's roots and appreciating women's skills in decision-making positions. Women also make up 84% of Hcor's Corporate Governance, 57% of its Executive Leadership, and 65% of its permanent workforce, showcasing the organization's commitment to promoting women's participation and leadership.

title: Avenida Paulista recebe ação de conscientização da asma grave e outras doenças
summary: On May 5th, Avenida Paulista in São Paulo will host a cultural event organized by Yabá Consultoria, Sanofi Brasil, and the Brazilian Association of Asthmatics (Abra) to raise awareness for World Severe Asthma Day. The event aims to highlight the importance of managing severe asthma and other chronic diseases. It will feature a theatrical group using clowning to provoke thought and reflection on societal issues. The event will take place at the Fiesp building and include stations where specialists will discuss related health topics. An "instagrammable" lung-shaped bench will be available for visitors to take photos for social media. The initiative seeks to inform a large audience about severe asthma and encourage regular health check-ups, leveraging the high pedestrian traffic on Sundays when Avenida Paulista is open only to pedestrians and cyclists.

title: Asma grave: só com 5 anos e crises controladas ela pôde correr e brincar
summary: Giovana Cipriano, a 9-year-old girl, has suffered from severe asthma since she was a baby, which resulted in frequent hospitalizations and a significant impact on her quality of life and that of her family. After a late diagnosis and initially inadequate treatment that caused severe side effects such as hypertension and delayed bone growth, Giovana finally received the appropriate care. Around the age of 5, after stabilizing her asthmatic crises, she was able to start running and playing, significantly improving her quality of life. Her mother, Raíssa, faced significant emotional and financial challenges during this period, including being fired for missing work to take care of Giovana. The experience led Raíssa to create an NGO to support other families facing similar problems. Severe asthma is a chronic condition that affects patients' lives due to inflammation in the airways, requiring specific and specialized treatments to control symptoms and improve the quality of life.

title: Campanha garante mais de 300 kg de alimentos para ONG Paravidda
summary: The Academia Fight Fit, part of the Grupo Machida, organized a campaign that successfully donated over 300 kg of non-perishable food items to the ONG Paravidda, an organization dedicated to supporting individuals with AIDS and viral hepatitis. The donations were collected from students and visitors of the academy. To encourage participation, the academy offered a day of training for every 1kg of food donated. This initiative comes at a crucial time for Paravidda, which has seen a decrease in contributions recently. The organization relies entirely on donations to support its users and provide food security through the distribution of basic food baskets to families in need. The campaign has been praised for its social responsibility and commitment to improving the quality of life for those supported by Paravidda.

title: Gestos lança campanha por mais recursos para a Política de Aids em parceria com quatro redes nacionais de pessoas ...
summary: Gestos, an NGO, launched the campaign "+ Resources Now for the AIDS Policy" in collaboration with four national networks of people living with HIV/AIDS. This initiative, supported by the Viiv Healthcare Foundation, aims to increase government funding for Brazil's national HIV/AIDS policy. The campaign, emerging from the "Protecting the AIDS Policy" project, involves 24 activists who helped create materials to highlight the urgent need for more investment. It features five videos narrated by activists from across the country, to be shared weekly on social media. The campaign seeks to strengthen Brazil's response to HIV, addressing the severe cutbacks in funding and the alarming rate of new infections, especially among women and girls aged 15 to 34. Gestos emphasizes the necessity of increased resources to improve access to new technologies, treatments, and prevention strategies, advocating for a detailed budget analysis to ensure substantial support for affected communities.

title: ONG Gestos e Alepe organizam exposição Faces do HIV
summary: The NGO Gestos and Alepe have organized the "Faces of HIV" exhibition, starting at 4 pm on Monday, December 4th, at the Edifício Governador Miguel Arraes in Recife. This free event, part of the December Red campaign for HIV/AIDS and STI awareness, showcases photographs of individuals living with HIV who have chosen to confront stigma and prejudice by sharing their experiences. The exhibition, running until December 15th, also includes a debate featuring some of the photographed individuals, professionals from the institution, and members of the Gestos Youth Activism Work Group. The exhibition aims to combat discrimination and is particularly relevant in Brazil, where a significant portion of people living with HIV/AIDS have faced stigma. This initiative highlights the courage of those willing to share their stories, aiming to foster a more inclusive and understanding society.

title: ONG Gestos lança campanha 'Eu e Meu/Minha Profissional da Saúde' para homenagear profissionais que atuam ...
summary: The NGO Gestos has launched the 3rd edition of the campaign ‘Me and My Health Professional’ in partnership with the International Aids Society (IAS) to honor health professionals who provide welcoming and non-discriminatory care to people living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA). This initiative, aimed at combating discrimination in healthcare settings, invites PLWHAs to nominate outstanding healthcare workers in Pernambuco and Paraíba, Brazil. Nominations are confidential and open to all healthcare professions, with a deadline of March 31. Selected nominees and their nominators will be celebrated remotely at the 25th International Aids Conference in Brisbane, Australia. This campaign, first introduced in Brazil in 2019 by Gestos, highlights the importance of empathy and respect in healthcare, addressing the challenge of stigma and discrimination faced by PLWHAs in accessing treatment.

title: Foaesp e Mopaids publicam cartas em defesa do CRT/Aids de São Paulo e pedem mais investimentos na luta contra a ...
summary: Foaesp and Mopaids have published letters advocating for the CRT/Aids of São Paulo, urging increased investments in the fight against AIDS in the state. Amidst rumors of changes within the São Paulo State Health Secretariat affecting the CRT, these organizations emphasize the center's crucial role in Brazil and globally in responding to AIDS. Foaesp highlighted the State Program and CRT's importance in advancing AIDS policy, citing a 78% decrease in AIDS mortality in São Paulo since 1995. They call for maintaining the CRT's current structure to prevent setbacks in HIV/AIDS cases and response. Mopaids stresses the need for new services, more health professionals, and innovative treatment and prevention technologies, focusing on the needs of vulnerable populations. Despite fears of the CRT being affected by governmental restructuring, Regiane Cardoso de Paula from the CCD clarified that there will be no changes to the CRT, which will continue its mission under a new subsecretary of Health Surveillance, aiming for a more dynamic, accessible, and comprehensive approach to AIDS in São Paulo.

title: El MiCOF está “doblemente satisfecho” con la sentencia que avala el decreto de SPFA | @diariofarma
summary: The Official College of Pharmacists of Valencia (MiCOF) expresses its double satisfaction for a ruling by the Supreme Court that supports the Valencian decree on the agreement of professional pharmaceutical care services (SPFA). This ruling legally validates the decree and recognizes the capacity of pharmacists to perform these services, in addition to allowing the necessary communication between pharmacies and Primary Care centers through computer systems, without direct access to clinical histories. This judicial decision is seen as a benefit for pharmacists, as it ratifies their right to perform certain health activities and establishes the bases for the inclusion of these services in the portfolio of the community pharmacy. The possibility of proposing the agreement of new services for future implementation is also contemplated.

title: Comienza el 23.º Congreso Nacional Farmacéutico en Valencia
summary: The 23rd National Pharmaceutical Congress began in Valencia, organized by the General Council of Pharmacists' Colleges (CGCOF) with collaboration from the Official College of Pharmacists of Valencia (Micof). Taking place at the Valencia Congress Palace from February 7th to 9th, the event's theme is "Transforming Healthcare with the Pharmacist." It features over 2,000 pharmacists, 150 speakers, 9 plenary sessions, and 34 technical and innovation sessions. The opening day included the inauguration of the 'Valentia Ars Pharmaceutica' historical exhibition and speeches by notable figures including Jesús Aguilar, president of the CGCOF; Jaime Giner, president of Micof; César Hernández from the Ministry of Health; and local government officials. The congress will also present reports on medication supply incidents and social determinants in health, culminating in a closing ceremony led by Aguilar, Giner, and Vicente José Mompó, president of the Valencia Provincial Council.

title: El MICOF, volcado en proyectos para la mejora del sistema sanitario y la salud de la población
summary: The Very Illustrious Official College of Pharmacists of Valencia (MICOF) has been actively involved in various projects aimed at improving the healthcare system and public health. Key initiatives include the establishment of a service for the community pharmacy-based dispensation of hospital medications, initiated as a pilot program in early 2021 during the COVID-19 pandemic to reduce hospital visits and contagion risks. This service, now permanently implemented, exemplifies the collaborative effort across the pharmaceutical channel, ensuring medication traceability and accessibility. Additionally, MICOF has signed agreements to integrate community pharmacists into public health matters, focusing on disease prevention and health education. Projects like the 'Sustainability of rural pharmacy' aim to maintain pharmaceutical care in rural areas, combating depopulation. MICOF also emphasizes professional pharmaceutical services, such as smoking cessation and diabetes detection, and has initiated educational programs for chronic disease patients. Collaborations with over 60 associations and entities further extend its outreach. The institution continues to advocate for the profession's integration into the healthcare system, highlighting its commitment to public health and professional development.

title: La ONCE dedica el diseño de un cupón al 23 Congreso Nacional Farmacéutico | @diariofarma
summary: The ONCE has dedicated the design of a coupon to the 23rd National Pharmaceutical Congress, which will be held in Valencia from February 7 to 9, 2024. This event, organized by the General Council of Official Colleges of Pharmacists in collaboration with the Very Illustrious Official College of Pharmacists of Valencia, is an important meeting for professionals in the pharmaceutical sector. The coupon, which will be distributed in five million copies on January 31, carries the slogan 'Transforming Health Care with the Pharmacist'. The congress will address crucial issues such as population aging, chronicity, dependency, digitalization, and polypharmacy, reflecting the essential role of pharmacists in the evolution of the health system. In addition, the ONCE Daily Coupon offers significant economic prizes to the winners.

title: Los estudiantes serán protagonistas en el Congreso Nacional Farmacéutico de Valencia
summary: At the 23rd National Pharmaceutical Congress in Valencia, from February 7 to 9, 2024, pharmacy students from across Spain will play a significant role. This event, organized by the General Council of Official Colleges of Pharmacists (Cgcof) with support from the Illustrious Official College of Pharmacists of Valencia, offers free attendance for 150 students on February 8. These students, from both the Valencian Community and other regions, will engage in all congress activities, with the Council covering their travel and registration, including lunch and congress materials. A special roundtable will discuss the career prospects of a Pharmacy degree, facilitating an exchange between universities, colleges, and students. Additionally, 17 students and/or recent graduates will help with organizational tasks, receiving compensation, meals, and invitations to the welcome reception and closing dinner. The organization also encourages faculties of Pharmacy to submit scientific presentations to showcase academic projects.

title: La profesión farmacéutica pone en valor seis siglos de historia en Valencia con su 23 Congreso Nacional
summary: Valencia hosts the 23rd National Pharmaceutical Congress, organized by the Very Illustrious Official College of Pharmacists of Valencia (MICOF) and the General Council of Colleges of Pharmacists (CGCOF), bringing together more than 2,000 professionals from all over the country. The event highlights the long history of pharmacy in Valencia, dating back to the creation of the College of Apothecaries in 1441, and celebrates almost six centuries of evolution and service. The exhibition "Valentia Ars Pharmaceutica" offers a journey through this history, from the 15th century to the present, showing the constant adaptation and innovation of the profession. In addition, issues such as drug shortages and the role of community pharmacy in the prevention and early detection of diseases are discussed. The congress also includes a pharmaceutical fallero monument and cultural activities, highlighting the profession's commitment to improving patient care.

title: 23 CNF: El próximo Congreso Nacional de Farmacéuticos será en Oviedo
summary: The 23rd National Congress of Pharmacists (23 CNF) concluded successfully, announcing that the next edition in the fall of 2026 will be held in Oviedo, Asturias. The event was notable for emphasizing the importance of the pharmacy profession in the health system, highlighting the need to integrate all health professionals within the National Health System (SNS). The award for the best communication was given to Augusto González Borrego for his work on the role of community pharmacy in the secondary prevention of skin cancer. The closing ceremony was attended by prominent figures such as Jaime Giner, president of the Official College of Pharmacists of Valencia; Jesús Aguilar, president of the General Council of Pharmacists; and institutional and business representatives. The commitment to sustainability was highlighted, with the congress being a "Green Sponsor" event, and the benefit for Ademuz, a town that benefits from the congress's carbon footprint compensation, was mentioned.

title: El Consell Valencià de Col·legis de Farmacèutics de la Comunitat inicia la campaña 'Abrígate contra el frío'
summary: The Valencian Council of Pharmacists' Associations of the Valencian Community has launched the "Bundle up against the cold" campaign to prevent and combat low temperatures, especially among risk groups. This initiative, supported by the Official Colleges of Pharmacy of Valencia, Castellón, and Alicante, focuses on informing patients through pharmacies about health risk levels and providing advice on facing the cold. Materials and infographics have been created to share on social networks and raise awareness about the dangers of the cold. Additionally, a webinar will be offered on January 16 to train pharmacists in health education about low temperatures. This campaign is part of an agreement with the Ministry of Universal Health and Public Health to coordinate public health actions, including training, patient information, research, and scientific dissemination.

title: Retos, preocupaciones y propósitos de la hematología española
summary: The Spanish Society of Hematology and Hemotherapy (SEHH) aims to strengthen ties with the Ministry of Health and other political entities to address challenges in hematology. Despite advancements in diagnostics and treatments, including CAR-T therapy, the specialty faces hurdles like extending residency training from 4 to 5 years and incorporating innovative therapies into the national health service. The availability of advanced treatments like CAR-T is limited, and efforts are ongoing to optimize patient access. Additionally, there's a push to develop national epidemiological registries for cancer, with hematological cancers being the fifth most common. The SEHH is also focused on personalizing medicine for hematological patients, leveraging diagnostic tools and artificial intelligence to improve treatment outcomes. These efforts are highlighted in their national congress and the III Ibero-American Congress of Hematology, emphasizing the specialty's pioneering and innovative nature.

title: Innovación inteligente para atacar el cáncer en España
summary: In Spain, cancer is the second leading cause of death, with blood cancers being among the most diagnosed yet incurable types. However, advancements in technology and innovation are leading towards the chronic management and potential cure of these cancers. Spain, after the United States, is second in the number of clinical trials, with over 900 conducted in 2022, mainly driven by the pharmaceutical industry. These trials, especially in their early stages, offer more therapeutic options for patients in advanced disease stages. The move towards non-chemotherapy treatments has improved patients' health outcomes, survival rates, and quality of life. Progress in understanding the biological and genetic aspects of blood cancers has led to innovative targeted therapies, notably in treating multiple myeloma. Despite these advancements, challenges remain in making these treatments widely available and overcoming public skepticism towards clinical trials. The future focus is on supporting research and development to continue advancing cancer treatment.

title: La financiación de los tratamientos oncohematológicos es uno de los principales desafíos para la SEHH
summary: The Spanish Society of Hematology and Hemotherapy (SEHH) faces the challenge of funding oncohematological treatments, highlighting problems in the approval and financing of medications, which limits patients' access to these. María Victoria Mateos, president of the SEHH, advocates for more collaboration between governments and regional societies to streamline the evaluation of medications and improve access to innovations. The SEHH has published the third edition of its report 'Advances in Hematological Cancer,' aiming to be a reference guide for various audiences. Additionally, the organization prepares Position Reports to guide administrations in decision-making about medications, from a scientific perspective. Mateos criticizes the situation of patients who must change their residence to access treatments and highlights Spain's leadership in clinical trials, though she points out the need to generalize access to innovation.

title: Estudian el efecto de la aféresis terapéutica en la enfermedad de Alzhéimer | @diariofarma
summary: The Spanish Society of Hematology and Hemotherapy (SEHH) and the Spanish Group of Apheresis (GEA) organized the First National Apheresis Course, aimed at hematologists and nursing professionals involved in apheresis procedures. The course, which saw over a thousand registrants from Spain and Latin America, covered therapeutic apheresis, telepheresis, quality systems in apheresis units, cell therapy, and photopheresis, with significant focus on therapeutic apheresis for treating various diseases. It highlighted the increasing need for knowledge in apheresis due to technological advancements in the field. A significant part of the course was dedicated to therapeutic apheresis, a process of removing disease-causing components from plasma or replacing deficient factors, which is crucial for treating conditions like Guillain-Barré Syndrome and intoxications. The course also addressed the growing demand for immunoglobulin, coagulation factors, and other plasma-derived substances, contrasting with the decreasing blood donations. Additionally, the potential of therapeutic apheresis in treating early stages of Alzheimer's disease was discussed, referencing preliminary results from the AMBAR study that showed clinical improvements in patients.

title: El Servicio de Hematología y Hemoterapia del Hospital Universitario Infanta Leonor se alza con el primer premio de ...
summary: The Hematology and Hemotherapy Service of the Infanta Leonor University Hospital won the first prize for clinical cases at the 9th Meeting of the Spanish Group of Hemogeriatrics of the Spanish Society of Hematology and Hemotherapy (SEHH) in Bilbao. The awarded case, presented by the resident doctors Dr. Victoria Ramos de Ascanio and Dr. Alejandro Sánchez Salto, under the direction of Dr. Sara Martínez Flores and Dr. Isabel González Gascón y Marín, highlighted the benefits of comprehensive geriatric assessment in the treatment of a 78-year-old patient with low-grade follicular lymphoma and several comorbidities. The assessment allowed the chemotherapy treatment to be adapted to her level of frailty, demonstrating the importance of comprehensive geriatric assessment in therapeutic personalization and in improving survival and reducing toxicity in patients with lymphoma.

title: La SEHH destaca el impacto de las técnicas moleculares en el ámbito de la Hematología
summary: The Spanish Society of Hematology and Hemotherapy (SEHH) emphasized the importance of molecular research in Hematology at its Annual Meeting in Madrid. Molecular techniques are fundamental in the diagnosis and treatment of blood diseases, allowing the development of targeted gene therapies. Mª Teresa Gómez Casares, president of the Molecular Biology in Hematology Group (GBMH), highlighted the need to incorporate new technologies in laboratories to improve the sensitivity and precision of diagnoses. Guidelines for the study of germinal hematological neoplasms were presented, and the importance of massive sequencing (NGS) in the clinical management of these diseases was addressed. Additionally, the profile of relapses in acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) was discussed, highlighting the challenges that the treatment of relapses presents due to changes in the genetic mutation pattern.

title: Piden un mayor acceso a terapias avanzadas en Hematología
summary: During the 65th National Congress of the Spanish Society of Hematology and Hemotherapy (SEHH) held in Sevilla, María Victoria Mateos Manteca, the president of SEHH, emphasized the need for greater access to innovative and advanced therapies such as CAR-T therapy and the implementation of artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance patient management in blood cancer treatments, aiming for personalized precision medicine. The congress highlighted the potential of AI in predicting the approach to multiple myeloma, the second most common blood cancer, by prioritizing the most effective treatments and minimizing adverse events. Additionally, the congress discussed the advancements in thrombosis treatment, including gene therapy for curing hemophilia by modifying the genome. The event also showcased the strengths of Andalusia's bone marrow transplant system and the ongoing developments in treating coagulopathies, particularly hemophilia, with significant therapeutic advancements.

title: “El problema no es el retraso en aprobación de fármacos, sino que no se financien” | @diariofarma
summary: The Spanish Society of Hematology and Hemotherapy (SEHH) highlights financing treatments for blood cancers as a significant challenge in Spain. In the updated report 'Advances in Hematological Cancer,' SEHH President María Victoria Mateos emphasizes the issue is not the delay in drug approvals but the lack of funding for these drugs, preventing patient access. Despite Spain's leadership in clinical trials, the general access to innovative treatments remains limited, contributing to global availability but not domestically. Mateos criticizes the inequity of treatment access within Spain and urges for improved collaboration among regional governments and hematological societies to expedite evaluation processes. The report also notes an estimated 28,657 blood cancer diagnoses in Spain in 2024, with varying survival rates based on cancer type, sex, and age group.

title: Plantan robles en el parque de Etxebarria de Bilbao para mejorar la salud
summary: In Bilbao, the City Council, in collaboration with the Spanish Society of Rheumatology, has begun the planting of oak trees in Etxebarria Park as part of an effort to improve environmental quality and combat rheumatic diseases. This action seeks to reverse the carbon footprint generated by the 9th Symposium on Autoimmune Diseases, contributing to the Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 Agenda. The initiative also aims to make Bilbao a greener and healthier city, recognizing the direct influence of the environment on the health and well-being of the population. Experts highlight health risks associated with climate change, air pollution, and the loss of biodiversity, which can exacerbate cardiovascular, respiratory, and rheumatic diseases.

title: La Junta crea el Instituto de Salud como fusión de Escuela de Salud Pública y Fundación Progreso y Salud "a coste cero"
summary: The Andalusian Regional Government has approved the creation of the Andalusian Health Institute, resulting from the merger of the Andalusian School of Public Health and the Progress and Health Foundation, claiming that the process will not involve additional costs. This new institute, which will also integrate parts of the organizational chart of the Ministry of Health and Consumption, is part of the efforts to streamline the public sector and improve efficiency in management. The measure has generated criticism from Por Andalucía and CCOO, who see behind it intentions to cover up poor management and privatize services. The Health Institute will adopt the legal form of an Administrative Agency and will aim to promote research, innovation, and excellence in healthcare, among other things. It will have staff from different categories and is expected to boost biomedical and health sciences research in the region.

title: Los investigadores reivindican en Sevilla la importancia de la financiación de sus proyectos sobre el cáncer
summary: Researchers in Seville highlight the importance of funding their cancer projects. The Spanish Association Against Cancer (AECC) and the Progreso y Salud Foundation organized an event with oncology experts to increase visibility for research as a tool to improve survival rates. The event, held in anticipation of World Cancer Research Day, featured discussions on the necessity of sustained research funding, the role of research in advancing precision medicine for rare cancers like Ewing's sarcoma, and the development of innovative therapies such as CAR-T at the Virgen del Rocío Hospital. The AECC has allocated 104 million euros to 565 oncological research projects, emphasizing the need for more funding and social recognition for researchers. The lack of investment in research in Spain compared to other countries was criticized, and the vital role of research in addressing health problems quickly, as demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic, was underscored. The event also showcased projects exploring therapeutic properties of stem cells in neurological diseases and advanced therapies for cancer.

title: Congreso SEEO 2023
summary: The SEEO 2023 Congress, the 19th National and 3rd International Congress of the Spanish Society of Oncology Nursing, will be held on May 25, 2023, at Baluarte, with various sessions scheduled throughout the day. This event aims to advance the specialization and social vision of oncology nursing, focusing on science, research, and the latest developments in oncological care. It seeks to enhance the knowledge and quality of care for cancer patients and their families. Approximately 400 professionals from diverse fields such as Cardiology, Oncology Nursing, Hematology, and Psychiatry, among others, will participate. The congress will provide a multidisciplinary platform for learning, discovery, and sharing experiences and insights. Baluarte is part of the public society of the Government of Navarra, NICDO, which promotes Culture, Sports, and Leisure.

title: MSD Y La Fundación ECO Presentan #HISTORIASDEVIDA Para Mostrar A La Sociedad Las Experiencias De ...
summary: MSD and the ECO Foundation have launched #HISTORIASDEVIDA to share experiences of overcoming cancer with society. This initiative, presented in Madrid, aims to destigmatize cancer by sharing personal stories from various perspectives, including patients, healthcare professionals, and researchers. The campaign features eleven individuals connected to oncology, whose stories are told through seven audiovisual snippets. These testimonials offer insights into the personal and emotional aspects of living with cancer, beyond the medical perspective. The project, which will continue over time, seeks to normalize the experiences of those dealing with cancer daily and contribute to the fight against the disease's stigma. Collaborators include the Foundation MÁS QUE IDEAS, the Spanish Society of Oncology Nursing, and the Spanish Association for Cancer Research. The testimonial videos are available on www.historiasdevida.net and will be promoted on social media under the hashtag #HistoriasdeVida.

title: Nuevos medicamentos contra el lupus y la artritis | ORM
summary: The XI Congress of the Murcian Society of Rheumatology, held in Cartagena, has presented new pharmacological treatments for lupus, arthritis, and sclerosis. These advances were announced with the goal of promoting the study of rheumatic diseases and improving patient care, also promoting the early detection of these conditions. During the event, which featured the participation of prominent rheumatologists from the Region of Murcia and all over Spain, the importance of maintaining healthy lifestyle habits to prevent the development of rheumatic diseases was highlighted. The vice president of the Murcian Society, Fernando Rodríguez, mentioned that the new medicines have already been tested and are close to being marketed. Additionally, it was noted that in the Region of Murcia, good rheumatology services are offered, except for the Hospital of Yecla, where a specialist is lacking.

title: «En EPOC hemos ganado años de calidad de vida para nuestros pacientes»
summary: José Luis Izquierdo Alonso, head of the Pneumonia Service at the Hospital of Guadalajara, has been named "Pulmonologist of the Year 2022" by the Madrid Society of Pulmonology and Thoracic Surgery through the Neumomadrid Foundation. This recognition is due to his dedication of more than three decades to Pulmonology, especially to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), from teaching, research, and healthcare. His work has significantly contributed to improving the quality of life of patients with COPD, changing the disease's profile thanks to treatments and care, allowing patients to be admitted less and at an older age. Additionally, he has focused on the importance of prevention and adapting to new technologies and personalized care strategies to face current challenges in respiratory health.

title: Pacientes, deportistas y sanitarios correrán en marzo por la salud renal
summary: Patients, athletes, healthcare professionals, and sports enthusiasts will participate on March 10 in the 'III Solidarity Race of World Kidney Day,' organized in Juan Carlos I Park in Madrid. This event, under the slogan 'Move for kidney health,' is driven by the Spanish Society of Nephrology (SEN) and the Senefro Foundation, with support from the Madrid City Council and 'Sport Life' magazine. Its purpose is to raise awareness about Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD), which affects 15% of adults in Spain, and to promote physical exercise as a preventive measure. The race will include different categories and distances, and its proceeds will go to improvement projects for kidney patients. Participants can register for the race in person in Madrid or virtually in their localities, with registrations open until February 26 for the virtual mode and until March 8 for the in-person mode.

title: XIII Reunión Nacional de Diálisis Peritoneal y Hemodiálisis Domiciliaria
summary: The XIII National Meeting on Peritoneal Dialysis and Home Hemodialysis is scheduled from February 22 to 24, 2024, at Baluarte, featuring various sessions across the Main Hall, Chamber Hall, Luneta, Ciudadela, and Main Lobby. Organized by the SENEFRO Foundation, the Spanish Society of Nephrology (S.E.N.), and the Spanish Society of Nephrological Nursing (SEDEN), the event aims to foster the exchange of ideas and experiences in peritoneal dialysis and home hemodialysis to enhance patient quality of life by offering more flexible and personalized treatment options. The three-day event will bring together experts in nephrology and home dialysis to share research, technological advancements, and clinical practices. It will include interactive sessions, practical workshops, and networking opportunities to promote future collaborations. Attendees must register to participate.

title: Abiertas las inscripciones para la Carrera Solidaria del Día Mundial del Riñón
summary: The II Solidarity Race for World Kidney Day will take place both in-person and virtually on March 5, 2023, at Juan Carlos I Park in Madrid, starting at 10:00 am. Organized by the Spanish Society of Nephrology/Senefro Foundation and the Madrid City Council, this event aims to highlight the importance of physical exercise for kidney health and raise awareness about Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD), which has seen a 30% increase in prevalence in Spain over the last decade. Nearly 65,000 Spaniards currently require Renal Replacement Therapy. The event also seeks to promote prevention and early diagnosis of CKD through a national Renal Health Plan. Registration fees for the 5 km race are 5€, and for children's races, 3€, with all proceeds going to the S.E.N.-ALCER program. Virtual race registrations have the same fee plus 4.95€ for shipping costs.

title: La XIII Reunión de Diálisis Peritoneal y Hemodiálisis Domiciliaria celebra hoy su segunda jornada en Baluarte
summary: The 13th Meeting of Peritoneal Dialysis and Home Hemodialysis, an important medical event, celebrates its second day today at Baluarte, organized by the SENEFRO Foundation, the Spanish Society of Nephrology (S.E.N.), and the Spanish Society of Nephrology Nursing (SEDEN). More than 500 professionals in nephrology, specialized nursing, and research from all over Spain and international speakers gather to discuss the latest advances and research in the treatment of Kidney Disease through Peritoneal Dialysis and Home Hemodialysis. This congress seeks to exchange ideas and knowledge to address the current challenges of kidney diseases, improve outcomes and the quality of life of patients, and raise awareness about Chronic Kidney Disease, which affects 15% of the adult population in Spain. Topics such as therapeutic innovations, strategies to increase the use of home dialysis techniques, benefits, and impact on the patient's life, among other relevant aspects, will be addressed.

title: La Junta incrementa la actividad y el personal de la Escuela Andaluza de Salud Pública
summary: The Andalusian Regional Government has increased the activity and staff of the Andalusian School of Public Health (EASP), attached to the Ministry of Health and Consumption. Last year, the EASP increased its training activity by 3%, with a total of 400 activities in which more than 73,000 professionals participated. Currently, it is in the process of hiring 4 new professionals, two from pharmacy and two from medicine, and is evaluating the offer of 8 new positions to comply with the replacement rate of public institutions. The school has also seen an increase in its consulting activity, carrying out 189 projects in 2023. In addition, the creation of the Andalusian Health Institute, which will integrate the EASP, and the candidacy of Granada as the headquarters of the National Public Health Agency were mentioned.

title: La Escuela Andaluza de Salud Pública, la Universidad de Granada y Roche Farma crean la Cátedra de Medicina ...
summary: The Andalusian School of Public Health, the University of Granada, and Roche Farma España have created the Chair of Medicine based on the 5P (personalized, predictive, preventive, participatory, and population-based), highlighting its importance for the future of medicine. During the presentation ceremony, the relevance of precision medicine and the need to focus healthcare on the patient were underscored. The importance of public-private collaboration in biomedical research to advance towards personalized medicine was emphasized. The Chair aims to develop scientific activities and projects that promote training, research, dissemination, and knowledge transfer in the field of 5P Medicine. The directors of the Chair, with outstanding research profiles, point to genomics, digital health, and the management of biomedical data as key elements for the success of personalized medicine.

title: La Escuela Andaluza de Salud Pública acoge la I Jornada Provincial de Humanización en Granada
summary: The Andalusian School of Public Health hosted the 1st Provincial Day of Humanization in Granada, focused on humanization in the socio-health field under the motto 'Humanization in 3D: Patients, caregivers, and professionals'. The event, which had more than 150 registered professionals, sought to highlight the importance of humanization in the sector, promote the exchange of experiences among professionals from all working categories of Granada's health centers, and promote the improvement of health services. Inaugurated by Francisco Javier Vázquez, Secretary General of Humanization, Planning, Socio-Health Care, and Consumption, the day included an opening conference by Miguel Melguizo, a specialist in Family and Community Medicine, and round tables that addressed the work of health professionals, the work of caregivers, and the figure of the patient. The need to focus attention on the patient and their relatives was highlighted, and initiatives such as the Humanization Plan and the Program for the Implementation of Good Practices in Care were mentioned.

title: La Junta consuma la extinción de la EASP con la aprobación del nuevo Instituto de Salud de Andalucía
summary: The Junta de Andalucía has approved the creation of the new Institute of Health of Andalucía, leading to the closure of the Andalusian School of Public Health (EASP). This move aims to streamline the public sector in Andalusia by consolidating health training and research entities and simplifying their legal framework. The government spokesperson stated that the Institute's establishment would not involve extra costs or lead to layoffs, as all staff from the EASP and the Andalusian Public Foundation for Progress and Health will be absorbed by the new institute. The location of the Institute's headquarters is yet to be announced. The Institute will focus on fostering research, innovation, and health training in Andalusia and will take over some administrative duties from the Health and Consumption Council, specifically the General Secretariat of Public Health and R&D+i in Health.

title: La Ley de creación del Instituto de Salud entra en el Parlamento con la “extinción” de la EASP y deja en el aire la sede ...
summary: The definitive project for the creation of the Andalusian Health Institute has been submitted to the Andalusian Parliament, marking the end of the Andalusian School of Public Health (EASP) without determining the location for the new agency. Despite significant opposition from the scientific, social, union, and political sectors, the PP, with an absolute majority, is advancing the legislation that will dissolve not only the EASP but also the Andalusian Public Foundation for Progress and Health. The law details the transfer of the entities' objectives, functions, personnel, and assets to the new administrative body, thereby abolishing their existing legal statuses. The future of the employees is in jeopardy, as they must participate in public exams to be considered for positions within the Junta. The legislation does not specify the headquarters for the new Institute, despite demands for it to be located in Granada. The establishment of the Institute is intended to improve the management of public research, development, innovation, and health quality, by incorporating the functions and staff of the current entities and part of the administrative structure of the health department.

title: Decálogo para tratar la salud mental en medios de comunicación
summary: The Federation of Autonomous Radio and Television Organizations (FORTA) and the Spanish Society of Psychiatry and Mental Health (SEPSM) have created a decalogue of recommendations for the treatment of mental health in the media, highlighting the importance of proper awareness and the correct use of language to avoid stereotypes and stigmatizations. Given the growing concern for mental health-related disorders in Spain, especially after the Covid-19 pandemic, and the lack of resources to address them, the involvement of the media in promoting an accurate and respectful image of mental health is considered crucial. The decalogue urges journalists to inform themselves correctly, avoid generalizations and prejudices, and respect the privacy and dignity of people with mental health issues, among other points, to positively contribute to public awareness and understanding of these issues.

title: ¿Hay una epidemia de TDAH? - Ethic
summary: The article discusses the significant rise in Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) diagnoses, suggesting that while increased awareness and research have improved diagnosis rates, there's also a concern about overdiagnosis and false positives. In Spain, 6.8% of minors and adolescents meet the clinical criteria for ADHD, with about 3% of the adult population also affected. Despite ADHD being primarily diagnosed in childhood, symptoms can persist into adulthood. The article raises questions about whether societal changes, such as the fast pace of life and the pervasive use of technology, may contribute to behaviors previously considered normal in children now being labeled as ADHD. It also addresses the issues of both overdiagnosis and underdiagnosis, highlighting the importance of accurate diagnosis by experienced specialists. The article concludes by emphasizing the need for greater understanding of ADHD to distinguish between genuine psychological/psychiatric issues and the impact of societal pressures.

title: ¿Por qué crece sin parar el número de menores con trastornos mentales en España?
summary: The Spanish Society of Psychiatry and Mental Health has highlighted a progressive increase in mental disorders in Spain, especially among minors and the elderly, due to the lack of resources for their care. Spain has a ratio of psychiatrists per inhabitant lower than that recommended by the WHO and those of reference countries, a situation that could worsen due to a future deficit of professionals due to retirements and the emigration of psychiatrists to countries with better conditions. Only Catalonia and the Basque Country have a ratio of psychiatrists above the recommended one. The lack of capacity to attract and retain professionals in the public system is a significant problem, with calls to improve working conditions. More than 1,500 professionals gather at the National Congress of Psychiatry in Salamanca to discuss these challenges. It is estimated that one in four people in Spain could have some mental disorder, with certain groups, such as women, children, the elderly, and immigrants, being especially vulnerable.

title: Tres de cada 10 españoles padecen algún trastorno de salud mental
summary: On World Mental Health Day, the Spanish Society of Psychiatry and Mental Health (SEPSM) highlighted that 29% of Spaniards suffer from a mental disorder, with anxiety disorders being the most common. This issue has become a priority for public health, especially after the COVID-19 pandemic. Spain currently has 4,393 psychiatrists in the public mental health sector, which is lower compared to other European countries. This shortage and regional disparities in access to mental health services have been identified as significant issues. The SEPSM proposes several measures to improve mental health care in Spain, including increasing the number of psychiatrists, enhancing mental health service networks, and promoting mental health initiatives in workplaces. Additionally, the World Health Organization and the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights have introduced a guide to prevent human rights abuses in mental health care and ensure access to quality care.

title: Doctora Marina Díaz Marsá: Retos de la salud mental para 2024
summary: Dr. Marina Díaz Marsá, vice president of the Spanish Society of Psychiatry and Mental Health (SEPSM), discusses the challenges of mental health for 2024, highlighting the growing importance of this area since the Covid-19 pandemic. She emphasizes the need to continue strengthening psychiatry in Spain to maintain quality care in the face of current and future challenges. She notes that 29% of the Spanish population suffers from some mental disorder, with anxiety, sleep disorders, and depression being the most common. Suicide is the leading cause of external death in the country, especially among young people. Marsá advocates for increasing human and care resources in psychiatry, improving working conditions to prevent burnout among specialists, and promoting collaboration between patient associations and scientific societies. She also emphasizes the importance of involving those affected and their caregivers in the formulation of strategies and evaluation of services.

title: Un decálogo para no presentar a las personas con trastornos mentales como locos o perturbados
summary: The Federation of Autonomous Radio and Television Organizations (FORTA) and the Spanish Society of Psychiatry and Mental Health (SEPSM) have created a decalogue of recommendations aimed at journalists and media professionals to avoid the stigmatization of people with mental disorders. The decalogue, coordinated by Dr. Luis Caballero, advises against generalizations, the use of correct and inclusive language, and the separation of mental disorders from crime reporting. It also emphasizes the importance of not exaggerating the limitations of patients and avoiding the false association between mental illness and violence. The increase in mental disorders, especially after the Covid-19 pandemic, and the lack of resources to address them, underline the need for accurate media representation. Both organizations hope that the decalogue will promote greater awareness and proper use of language to eradicate stigmas and sensationalist presentations about mental health.

title: | La semFYC defiende la labor realizada por la Comisión Nacional de la Especialidad de Medicina Familiar y ...
summary: The Spanish Society of Family and Community Medicine (semFYC) defends the work of the National Commission for the Specialty of Family and Community Medicine in the development of the new teaching program. This program seeks to update and adapt the training to current needs, responding to the evolution of clinical practice towards a more person-centered approach, prevention, and community care. The semFYC urges the Ministry of Health to expedite the processing of this program, essential for the National Health System, so that it can be implemented as soon as possible. This momentum is crucial given that the current program will soon be twenty years old and needs to reflect changes in the population, such as aging and the increase in chronic diseases, to properly prepare future professionals.

title: La Asociación Española de Pediatría apuesta por la educación y la formación en el uso de las pantallas
summary: The Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP) emphasizes the importance of education and training in the use of screens by children and adolescents, advocating for a healthy use of tablets and mobile phones rather than outright bans. AEP's stance comes in response to debates about the appropriate age for children to use technological devices. The association has launched the '#ChangeThePlan' campaign, in collaboration with the Spanish Data Protection Agency, to minimize health risks associated with screen misuse. AEP argues for a collective approach involving parents, schools, child protection institutions, and tech companies to safeguard children's physical, mental, social health, and neurodevelopment. It also calls for regulations to ensure apps for minors do not misuse personal data for advertising, offer age-appropriate content, and limit usage time, alongside measures to enforce current age regulations for social media use and prevent minors' access to adult content.

title: ¿A qué edad pueden ver dibujos?, ¿y usar el móvil?: así debe utilizar un niño la tecnología
summary: The Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP) has created the Family Digital Plan, a guide to help with the problem of children overusing screens. Only 36% of young people follow the World Health Organization's advice on how much screen time is okay, and this drops to 16% on weekends. Too much use of technology is now seen as a new thing that could make children more likely to be obese, which is over 40% in the country, and also lead to being alone, feeling depressed, having trouble sleeping, doing things too much like being on the internet, being bullied online, and seeing things they shouldn't like pornography. The AEP says it's important to not use screens too much for all ages, and suggests that kids under two should mostly just make video calls with their family. Kids aged three to five should only watch screens for less than an hour a day and it should be good quality shows. Kids from six to nine should move around and play for at least an hour a day and not spend too much time on screens. The guide also talks about how important it is for parents to be involved and set a good example with how they use their own digital devices to help their kids develop healthy habits.

title: Los casos de tosferina en aumento tras el parón de la pandemia
summary: Following the COVID-19 pandemic, there has been an increase in whooping cough cases, especially in Denmark and Spain. During the pandemic, containment measures such as the use of masks and limiting social interaction significantly reduced the incidence of whooping cough. However, with the lifting of these measures, Denmark has reported an increase in cases since May 2023, particularly among young people aged 10 to 18 and adults, while Spain has seen a resurgence since June, with 1230 cases recorded in September 2023, compared to 142 in the same period of 2022. Although vaccination among children and pregnant women remains high, the disease maintains an endemic presence with outbreaks every 3-5 years. The current increase in cases underscores the importance of continuing vaccination campaigns to contain the disease.

title: La Asociación Española de Pediatría celebra su 70º congreso sobre los puntos clave de la especialidad
summary: The Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP) celebrates its 70th Congress in Cordoba from June 6 to 8, available both in-person and online. This event will focus on the fundamental aspects of pediatrics, covering everything from the environmental impact on child health to rickets. Various presentations and debates will be offered, providing tools to address diseases and pathologies in children and adolescents. Additionally, there will be opportunities to present scientific posters and oral communications, with the possibility of winning awards. Topics include risk analysis for acute kidney damage in neonates, childhood obesity, and mobile phone use in the pediatric population. The congress will also announce scholarships and awards for training and research in 2024 and will offer training workshops on lung ultrasound, sutures, and echoguided procedures, among others. Registration is open for in-person attendance and via streaming.

title: Los 20 consejos de los pediatras para educar a tus hijos en el buen uso de Internet y la tecnología
summary: The Spanish Pediatric Association (AEP) has developed the AEP Family Digital Plan, offering a guide tailored to each family's needs and the ages of the children involved. This initiative comes in response to the widespread use of computers and the internet among minors under 16 in Spain, emphasizing technology's permanence in our lives. Acknowledging the particular vulnerability of children and adolescents to the risks associated with digital technology use, the AEP highlights the importance of educating them on its proper use. The AEP's guide includes 20 recommendations for families, such as limiting screen time based on age, promoting physical activity, ensuring proper posture during device use, establishing screen-free zones, encouraging creative technology use, choosing age-appropriate content, fostering critical thinking and digital empathy, and conducting regular device check-ups with children to respect their privacy while identifying and mitigating risks early.

title: 15 de febrero, Día Internacional del Cáncer Infantil, comunicado de la Sociedad Española de Hematología y Oncología ...
summary: February 15 is celebrated as International Childhood Cancer Day, and the Spanish Society of Pediatric Hematology and Oncology (SEHOP), part of the Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP), uses this date to highlight that the survival rate of children under 14 years old with cancer in Spain is 82% at five years, according to the most recent data from 2022 of the Spanish Registry of Childhood Tumors (RETI-SEHOP). This statement was published on February 13, 2023, and last reviewed on February 22, 2023.

title: Catorce recomendaciones sobre los que trabajar en Pediatría
summary: During the first week of October, Pediatrics Week, the Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP) developed a manifesto with 14 recommendations to improve pediatric care, coinciding with the celebration of 'Día P' on October 8. These recommendations highlight the importance of collaborative work among families, healthcare professionals, and institutions to educate children and adolescents on leading healthy lives. The manifesto emphasizes the need for up-to-date, scientifically-backed information on various health topics like vaccines, nutrition, breastfeeding, and healthy habits. It covers twelve key areas, including health promotion, vaccination, nutrition and breastfeeding, pediatric medication, pain management, sleep, environmental health, quality of care and patient safety, bioethics, solidarity, history and future of Pediatrics, and training and research. These areas are deemed crucial for maintaining excellence in pediatric care and ensuring the well-being of children and adolescents.

title: La Facultad de Medicina firmó un convenio de intercambio internacional
summary: The National University of Mar del Plata (UNMDP) and the Spanish Society of General Practitioners and Family Doctors (SEMG) have signed an international cooperation and exchange agreement to benefit medical students in both Argentina and Spain. The agreement, digitally signed by UNMDP rector Alfredo Lazzeretti and officials from both entities, targets postgraduate residents in Family and General Medicine in both nations. It aims to encourage participation in collaborative research projects with Latin American countries and in extension, transfer, and linkage activities within institutional programs of mutual interest. This initiative is viewed as a crucial opportunity at both the institutional and international levels to strategically enhance the training of postgraduate medical students, particularly during a period when health systems are confronting significant challenges.

title: El SUMMA 112, doblemente premiado en el Congreso de SEMES
summary: The Emergency Medical Service of the Community of Madrid (SUMMA 112) was doubly awarded at the XXXIII National Congress of the Spanish Society of Emergency and Emergency Medicine (SEMES) for its study 'Ventila Madrid' on non-invasive mechanical ventilation and for its attention to stroke. The study, led by Cristina Horrillo, showed improvements in the prognosis of patients with acute pulmonary edema and severe exacerbated COPD. In addition, SUMMA 112 was recognized with the Angels EMS Awards. About 80 professionals from SUMMA 112 actively participated in the event, contributing with 65 communications, courses, workshops, and presentations. The congress was held in Madrid from June 7 to 9, with the presence of important figures such as the Minister of Health, Enrique Ruiz Escudero, and the Minister of Health, José Manuel Miñones.

title: XXXIII Congreso Nacional SEMES 2023
summary: The XXXIII National Congress of SEMES 2023 is a significant event organized by the Spanish Society of Emergency Medicine (SEMES), featuring a comprehensive program that includes various activities such as an exhibition on multiple victim accidents, the inauguration act presented by Juan González Armengol and Carmen del Arco Galán, and participation from notable figures like Tato Vázquez Lima, President of SEMES; Inmaculada Sanz, Delegate of Security and Emergencies of Madrid City Council; Enrique Ruiz Escudero, Health Counselor of the Community of Madrid; José Manuel Miñones, Minister of Health; along with a talk by Iker Jiménez and a performance by Musical Thinkers. The event also provides access to courses for SEMES members through the Xpeer platform, with a photographic summary available for members. It emphasizes the importance of sharing the photographs with proper citation to SEMES.

title: 33 Congreso Nacional SEMES 2023 | IFEMA MADRID
summary: IFEMA MADRID will host the 33rd National SEMES Congress from June 7th to June 9th, 2023. The congress aims to unite experts uniquely and exclusively, meeting the varied and practical educational needs of attendees from different groups. A primary focus of the SEMES Congress is to incorporate new talents that emerge daily into society, demonstrating SEMES's skill in operating within multidisciplinary teams. The event offers a great atmosphere where attendees can enjoy every moment, emphasizing the integration of new values and the identity of society in promoting teamwork.

title: Retos para mejorar la calidad de los Servicios de Urgencias
summary: The National Congress of the Spanish Society of Emergency Medicine (SEMES), held in Madrid, gathered over 3,000 healthcare professionals to address the challenges in emergency services. The event featured over 200 activities focused on the latest treatments for various medical conditions. Key issues discussed included managing mass casualty incidents, the role of Artificial Intelligence in emergency medicine, increasing assaults on healthcare staff, and the impact of social media and fake news on suicide behavior. The congress aimed to educate emergency professionals on these topics, with a significant emphasis on protecting healthcare workers from violence, addressing suicide attempts effectively, combating health misinformation, utilizing AI to enhance emergency services, and efficiently managing incidents with multiple victims.

title: La creación de la Especialidad de Medicina de Urgencias y Emergencias en España, una realidad cada vez más ...
summary: The Spanish Society of Emergency Medicine (SEMES) has announced the imminent creation of the Specialty of Emergency Medicine in Spain, following the public consultation of the draft Royal Decree by the Ministry of Health. This development will allow for a core training of two years in common with Family and Community Medicine, in addition to offering flexibility in the health system for those who choose this specialty as their first option in the MIR (Medical Intern Resident). A process of recognition for professionals already working in these services will also be established, facilitating extraordinary access to the specialist title. This progress, according to SEMES president Dr. Tato Vázquez Lima, represents a decisive step in improving patient care and aligns Spain with European standards in the field of emergency medicine.

title: El Ministro de Sanidad, José Manuel Miñones, confirma el proceso de la creación de la Especialidad de Medicina de ...
summary: José Manuel Miñones, the Minister of Health, announced the beginning of the process to create the Specialty of Emergency Medicine during the inauguration of the XXXIII National Congress SEMES 2023. This announcement was well received by the professionals of the sector, including the vice president of SEMES, Carmen Camacho, who highlighted the commitment and sacrifice of emergency doctors. Enrique Ruiz Escudero, Minister of Health of the Community of Madrid, emphasized the importance of this specialty to improve the quality of healthcare and anticipated that Madrid will train 30 emergency specialists per promotion. Minister Miñones congratulated the emergency doctors and assured the continuous support of the Ministry of Health. SEMES leaders expressed their gratitude for the support to the specialty, considering this announcement as a strategic and planned milestone for the field.

title: El grupo de Diabetes de la Sociedad Española de Medicina de Urgencias y Emergencias (SEMES) y la Asociación ...
hco: Centro de Acao Humanitaria do Amazonas
summary: The Diabetes Group of the Spanish Society of Emergency Medicine (SEMES) and the Diabetes Madrid Association (ADM) have signed a collaboration agreement to develop summer camps for children and adolescents with diabetes. This project aims to educate, train, and support young people with this condition, involving healthcare personnel in the activities. The initiative seeks to promote patient autonomy in a relaxed environment, also offering training to professionals in diabetes, communication skills, and teamwork. This agreement is positively valued by both parties, highlighting its importance in the training of healthcare professionals and in supporting children with diabetes, providing peace of mind to their families.

title: Los profesionales de urgencias presentan una guía global para el tratamiento de sepsis y una aplicación para ...
hco: Centro de Acao Humanitaria do Amazonas
summary: Emergency professionals have introduced a comprehensive guide for sepsis treatment and an app for selecting antibiotic treatment during the second day of SEMES 2023. This guide, developed in collaboration with 13 Latin American societies, is unique in its international scope and focus on sepsis practice. It aims to introduce sepsis prevention, personalize patient care, and develop international clinical practice guidelines. The guide employs a rigorous methodological approach, utilizing emergency and community infection literature, and is expected to be published early next year. Additionally, efforts are being made to address antibiotic resistance, with a group presenting advances in rational antibiotic use in emergency services. An app developed by 9 scientific societies guides empirical antibiotic treatment selection for common infections. The conference also discussed improving care for elderly patients in emergency services, emphasizing the need for tailored care plans and service adaptation. Furthermore, a virtual reality space simulating a rescue operation from the recent Turkey and Syria earthquakes was showcased, highlighting the importance of training for emergency response teams.

title: Gilead colabora con SEMES para elaborar un consenso médico para manejar la Covid-19 en urgencias
summary: Gilead Sciences has collaborated with the Spanish Society of Emergency Medicine (SEMES) to develop a medical consensus for managing COVID-19 in emergency services. This initiative aims to offer recommendations for strategies that optimize patient treatment amidst ongoing challenges such as partial population immunization and less pathogenic virus variants. The document, titled "SEMES Positioning on Antiviral Treatment against SARS-CoV-2 in the Current Epidemiological Situation," was created with inputs from SEMES regional entities in Andalusia, Madrid, Valencia, and Catalonia. It emphasizes the importance of understanding COVID-19's significant threat, despite the availability of vaccines and effective antiviral treatments which have reduced hospitalizations, severity, and mortality. The protocol provides guidance on risk stratification, treatment of vulnerable individuals, and the use of antivirals both inside and outside hospitals, addressing the varied and heterogeneous clinical management observed in emergency services. This collaboration seeks to prevent inefficiencies or inequities in treating COVID-19 patients by establishing consolidated medical protocols and understanding infection risks across different population groups.

title: Los oftalmólogos temen que la gratuidad de gafas y lentillas genere sobrecarga y piden concreción
summary: Ophthalmologists are concerned about the Spanish Ministry of Health's plan to include glasses and contact lenses in the public health system's coverage starting in 2025. Dr. José Antonio Gegúndez, Secretary-General of the Spanish Society of Ophthalmology (SEO), expressed that the ministry did not consult their collective or provide details about the project. He highlighted the importance of consulting ophthalmologists, who are responsible for prescribing these optical aids, as refractive errors can sometimes indicate serious diseases. The initiative aims to prioritize those most in need and with the least access to these products, but the SEO warns of potential consequences, including increased workload for ophthalmologists and the need for clear regulation and consensus. The SEO urges the Ministry of Health to closely study the project and collaborate with healthcare professionals to ensure the strategy is viable and beneficial for patients truly in need.

title: Una empresa española crea un software clave para tratar enfermedades oftalmológicas y la primera causa de ceguera ...
summary: A Spanish company, Bahía Software, has developed an innovative software called Nazzar to revolutionize the diagnosis of ophthalmological diseases, including age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of blindness in people over 65. Presented at the 99th Congress of the Spanish Society of Ophthalmology, Nazzar uses artificial intelligence algorithms to provide secure support in clinical decision-making, allowing for more accurate and personalized diagnoses and treatments. This software seeks to improve efficiency in ophthalmological practice and optimize treatment costs. Additionally, it facilitates the structured collection of clinical data and improves the monitoring of patient progress, being a key tool for the treatment of pathologies such as AMD and macular edema, significantly contributing to innovation in the health field and improving the quality of life of patients.

title: El aviso de los oftalmólogos sobre los riesgos de cambiarse el color de los ojos ha surtido efecto
summary: The Spanish Society of Ophthalmology (SEO) has issued a warning about the dangers of undergoing procedures to change eye color, a trend promoted by some influencers. This alert has been effective to the extent that certain related content has been removed from social media, according to the new SEO president, Prof. José Manuel Benítez del Castillo. The warning comes amid concerns that such procedures could lead to severe eye damage, necessitating cornea transplants. The SEO aims to inform the public about potential health risks and has seen a positive response from the media and the removal of specific promotional content online.

title: La Sociedad Española de Oftalmología reconoce la trayectoria del catedrático de la UMH Jorge Alió
summary: Dr. Jorge Alió has been awarded by the Spanish Society of Ophthalmology (SEO) with the Castroviejo Prize in recognition of his outstanding professional career. This recognition took place at the 99th Congress of the SEO, held in Seville, where more than 2,000 ophthalmologists gathered. Alió, a professor of Ophthalmology at the Miguel Hernández University (UMH) of Elche, is internationally recognized for his research in keratoconus and advanced stem cell therapy. Additionally, he recently received the Binkhorst Medal and the medal of the International Intraocular Implant Club, and was ranked 12th in the ‘The Ophthalmologist Power List 2023’. In 2024, Alió will give a lecture at the centenary congress of the SEO in Madrid, an event that will bring together various specialized ophthalmological societies.

title: Intercambio de 'Sonrisas por Lágrimas' para concienciar sobre el ojo seco
summary: At the 99th Congress of the Spanish Society of Ophthalmology, Angelini Pharma highlighted dry eye syndrome, a common condition in ophthalmology consultations. The company launched the 'Smiles for Tears' campaign in collaboration with Banco Farmacéutico to raise awareness of the condition and help those in social exclusion access treatment. The initiative collects smiles through photographs on its website, and for each one, donates artificial tear packages to those with dry eye syndrome at risk of social exclusion. The campaign aims to address the high incidence of dry eye in Spain, affecting five million people and considered a public health problem worldwide. It emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis, the effectiveness of anti-inflammatory drugs, artificial tears, and technologies like pulsed light in treatment. The initiative concludes on World Smile Day, October 6, with the delivery of the product.

title: Los avances en tumores oculares, estrabismo y queratocono, temas principales del 99º Congreso de la SEO
summary: The 99th Congress of the Spanish Society of Ophthalmology (SEO) took place in Seville from September 27 to 29, attracting over 2,000 ophthalmologists from across Spain. This event served as a precursor to the centennial congress scheduled for next year in Madrid. The congress featured a comprehensive scientific program highlighting advancements in ocular tumors, strabismus, and keratoconus. Key presentations included an update on Ocular Oncology by Dr. María Antonia Saornil and Dr. José María Caminal, a roundtable on Adult Strabismus by Drs. Lucía de Pablo Gómez de Liaño and Alberto Reche Sainz, and discussions on intracorneal ring segments and regenerative therapy for corneal stroma. The congress emphasized the importance of these topics due to their specialization and the increasing demand for improved quality of life among adults with strabismus. Next year's congress in Madrid will also feature participation from various other societies related to ophthalmology.

title: El 90 % de las pérdidas de visión se pueden prevenir o tratar El 90 % de las pérdidas de visión se pueden prevenir o ...
summary: 90% of vision loss can be prevented or treated, according to the Spanish Society of Ophthalmology (SEO). This message is emphasized in commemoration of World Vision Day, which is celebrated on the second Thursday of October, this year on October 12. The World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) establish this day to raise awareness about visual conditions and their treatments. The SEO highlights the importance of eye care at work, encouraging employers to promote eye health among employees. Tips are offered such as ensuring proper lighting, maintaining correct visual ergonomics, taking regular breaks, protecting the eyes in risky occupations, and having regular eye exams. Additionally, it is reported that at least 771 million people have vision loss that could be prevented or treated through methods such as glasses, contact lenses, refractive surgery, or cataract surgery.

title: SEOM y SEFH trabajan en una atención oncológica más preventiva, efectiva, segura, humani
summary: The Spanish Society of Medical Oncology (SEOM) and the Spanish Society of Hospital Pharmacy (SEFH) collaborate on a project to improve cancer care, making it more preventive, effective, safe, humanized, and participatory. This work is articulated in ten chapters, developed by medical oncologists and hospital pharmacists, covering various strategies and perspectives, such as the incorporation of PROMs and PREMs in cancer care, comprehensive care in cancer patients, and the approach to oncogeriatric patients, among others. The project, presented in a joint webinar by SEOM and SEFH, seeks to advance a comprehensive approach to the cancer patient, highlighting the importance of collaboration between Medical Oncology and Hospital Pharmacy to benefit the cancer patient.

title: SEOM pone en marcha un registro de portadores de variantes genéticas germinales en genes de predisposición al ...
